351:
<p>Check out <a href="http://docs.python.org/3/library/time.html#time.strptime" rel="noreferrer">strptime</a> in the <a href="http://docs.python.org/3/library/time.html" rel="noreferrer">time</a> module.  It is the inverse of <a href="http://docs.python.org/3/library/time.html#time.strftime" rel="noreferrer">strftime</a>.</p>

<pre class="lang-py s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python">$ python
<span class="hljs-meta">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span><span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> time
<span class="hljs-meta">&gt;&gt;&gt; </span>my_time = time.strptime(<span class="hljs-string">'Jun 1 2005  1:33PM'</span>, <span class="hljs-string">'%b %d %Y %I:%M%p'</span>)
time.struct_time(tm_year=<span class="hljs-number">2005</span>, tm_mon=<span class="hljs-number">6</span>, tm_mday=<span class="hljs-number">1</span>,
                 tm_hour=<span class="hljs-number">13</span>, tm_min=<span class="hljs-number">33</span>, tm_sec=<span class="hljs-number">0</span>,
                 tm_wday=<span class="hljs-number">2</span>, tm_yday=<span class="hljs-number">152</span>, tm_isdst=-<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)

timestamp = time.mktime(my_time)
<span class="hljs-comment"># convert time object to datetime</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> datetime <span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> datetime
my_datetime = datetime.fromtimestamp(timestamp)
<span class="hljs-comment"># convert time object to date</span>
<span class="hljs-keyword">from</span> datetime <span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> date
my_date = date.fromtimestamp(timestamp)
</code></pre>

<pre class="lang-py s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-python">In [<span class="hljs-number">34</span>]: <span class="hljs-keyword">import</span> datetime

In [<span class="hljs-number">35</span>]: _now = datetime.datetime.now()

In [<span class="hljs-number">36</span>]: _now
Out[<span class="hljs-number">36</span>]: datetime.datetime(<span class="hljs-number">2016</span>, <span class="hljs-number">1</span>, <span class="hljs-number">19</span>, <span class="hljs-number">9</span>, <span class="hljs-number">47</span>, <span class="hljs-number">0</span>, <span class="hljs-number">432000</span>)

In [<span class="hljs-number">37</span>]: <span class="hljs-built_in">print</span> _now
<span class="hljs-number">2016</span>-01-<span class="hljs-number">19</span> 09:<span class="hljs-number">47</span>:<span class="hljs-number">00.432000</span>

In [<span class="hljs-number">38</span>]: _parsed = datetime.datetime.strptime(<span class="hljs-built_in">str</span>(_now),<span class="hljs-string">"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S.%f"</span>)

In [<span class="hljs-number">39</span>]: _parsed
Out[<span class="hljs-number">39</span>]: datetime.datetime(<span class="hljs-number">2016</span>, <span class="hljs-number">1</span>, <span class="hljs-number">19</span>, <span class="hljs-number">9</span>, <span class="hljs-number">47</span>, <span class="hljs-number">0</span>, <span class="hljs-number">432000</span>)

In [<span class="hljs-number">40</span>]: <span class="hljs-keyword">assert</span> _now == _parsed
</code></pre>
352:
<p>In case people are still having trouble with this.  I wrote a quick blog post about using Autolayout with UITableViews <a href="http://www.raizlabs.com/dev/2014/02/leveraging-auto-layout-for-dynamic-cell-heights/">Leveraging Autolayout For Dynamic Cell Heights</a> as well as an open source component to help make this more abstract and easier to implement.
<a href="https://github.com/Raizlabs/RZCellSizeManager">https://github.com/Raizlabs/RZCellSizeManager</a></p>

<p>If the cell height is dynamic by the content, you should precisely count it out and then return the height value before the cell is rendered. An easy way is to define the counting method in the table view cell code for controller to call at the table cell height delegate method. Don't forget to count out the <strong>real cell frame width</strong> (default is 320) if the height is rely on the width of the table or screen. That is, <strong>in the table cell height delegate method, use cell.frame to correct the cell width first, then call the counting height method defined in the cell to get the suitable value and return it</strong>. </p>

<p>PS. The code for generating cell object could be defined in another method for different table view cell delegate method to call.</p>
353: <p>I encountered the same error and got stalled with a pyspark dataframe for few days, <strong><em>I was able to resolve it successfully by filling na values with 0</em></strong> since I was comparing integer values from 2 fields.</p>
354: <p>If you are using sdk 23 or higher then you must check run time permissions.</p>

<p>List of All Permissions Can be Found with Explanation at</p>

<p><a href="https://developer.android.com/reference/android/Manifest.permission" rel="nofollow noreferrer">Manifest.permission</a></p>
355:
<p><code>==</code> is an <em>operator</em> and <code>equals()</code> is a <em>method</em>.</p>

<p>Operators are generally used for <em>primitive</em> type comparisons and thus <code>==</code> is used for memory address comparison and <code>equals()</code> method is used for comparing <em>objects</em>. </p>

<p>Both == and .equals() refers to the same object if you don't override .equals(). </p>

<p>Its your wish  what you want to do once you override .equals(). You can compare the invoking object's state with the passed in object's state or you can just call super.equals()</p>

<p>Also note that <code>.equals()</code> normally contains <code>==</code> for testing as this is the first thing you would wish to test for if you wanted to test if two objects are equal. </p>

<p>And <code>==</code> actually does look at values for primitive types, for objects it checks the reference.</p>
<p><code>==</code> can be used in many object types but you can use <code>Object.equals</code> for any type , especially Strings and Google Map Markers.</p>

<p>In short, the answer is "Yes".</p>

<p>In Java, the <code>==</code> operator compares the two objects to see if they point to the same memory location; while the <code>.equals()</code> method actually compares the two objects to see if they have the same object value.</p>
<p>In simple words, <code>==</code> checks if both objects point to the same memory location whereas <code>.equals()</code> evaluates to the comparison of values in the objects.</p>
